results.title: Rupert Murdoch
results.creator_credit: Kip Porteous, Ken Hannam and ABC
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Five Australians”
Looks at the personal life of Rupert Murdoch the newspaper tycoon, whose career started when he inherited the family company interests. He expanded the business and launched a national paper, The Australian. Members of his family and staff discuss the man they know.

results.title: Rupert Bunny: colour, mood & the senses
results.creator_credit: Lion's Den Productions, Reg McLean and Eugene Schlusser
results.brief_description: A detailed documentary examining the works and background of Australian artist, Rupert Bunny, focussing on the factors which made his work so admired by both collectors and fellow artists. Born in Melbourne, Bunny was one of the few Australian artists painting between the Romantic and Modernist periods to achieve international success by selling works all over the world. While his subjects ranged from mythological characters, seascapes, fairytales, and the spiritual, they all shared a common thread in that their purpose was to appeal to all of the senses. The concept of synthaesthesia - that one sense can be evoked by another - is strikingly evident in the sensuously elegant content of his paintings. A number of art critics offer their opinions on why they believe Bunny is one of the most masterly painters that Australia has ever produced.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Lion’s Den Productions, Reg McLean and Eugene Schlusser

results.title: Running water: landform evolution
results.creator_credit: Robert Lattanzio and Corporation for Community Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 20 of Series “Earth revealed”.
Recognizes the roles human activity can play in itensifying or reducing flood danger. Looks at how rivers cut into landscapes to produce wonders like the Grand Canyon and the formation of deltas and lakes where water and sediment is collected. This episode also looks at how geologists and engineers are tackling the problem of accumulation of silt and sediment in the Mississippi River where three rivers in the delta region are converging.

results.title: Running water: erosion & deposition
results.creator_credit: Robert Lattanzio and Corporation for Community Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 19 of Series “Earth revealed”.
What do rivers do? The power or velocity of river flow is responsible for some of the most unique sculpting of landforms on the planet. Running water transports sediments and deposits it at river mouths and deltas as well as abrasively smoothing and wearing away bedrock on its course. Geologists study the ways rivers flow and meander in order to solve problems of flooding and silting as well as assiting engineers in the construction of dams and dykes in order to improve flow of water.

results.title: Running water
results.creator_credit: John Selwyn Gilbert, Channel Four, Antelope Films and Network Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 7 of Series “Spaceship Earth”.
Managing the rivers will be an important part of managing global climate changes. Using satellite technologies, this program visits the great river basins of the planet - the Nile, Amazon, Mississippi, Ganges, Danube and the Yellow River. These mighty watercourses have a profound influence on the people who conduct their daily life along their banks.

results.title: Running time
results.creator_credit: George Pearson, Colin Low, Tom Daly, ONF | NFB and Mort Ransen
results.brief_description: This feature film is an exotic romp through the ‘60s in song and dance. A fantasy that pokes fun not only at some hallowed institutions but at itself as well. The friendship between an old lady and a young man sets off a chain of events that involves a number of well-intentioned middle-aged individuals in some outrageously bizarre situations. A parodic exposition of 1960’s social mores. While the film benefits from its elaborate arsenal of experimental cinematic techniques - split screen images, freeze frames, solarisation and multiple exposures, rapid edits - the narrative is disrupted by a succession of musical numbers. Unlike to so much else in the film, the music and acting styles are somewhat conventional, and detract from what might otherwise be the Canadian counterpart to Vera Chytilova’s “Daisies”.
results.creator_credit_for_label: George Pearson, Colin Low, Tom Daly, ONF | NFB and Mort Ransen

results.title: Running high: a story of pain and joy ...
results.creator_credit: South Australian Film Corporation and Gus Howard
results.brief_description: Novices and champions prepare for, and run the 1983 Festival City Marathon. Robert de Castella intersperses candid interviews with his marathon running philosophy and techniques. Discusses the exhilaration of personal improvement, the disappointment of hitting the wall and the reasons behind the increasing popularity of running throughout the world.

results.title: Running for life
results.creator_credit: Jack T. O'Grady and National Educational Television
results.brief_description: Gives the results of a two year experiment sponsored by the US Office of Public Health, to determine the effects of exercise on middle-aged persons - and whether such exercising can reduce the chances of heart disease. Shows faculty members of the University of Wisconsin exercising and reporting of their experiences.

results.title: Running and mobility (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Brian Hannant, Nicholas Cockram, Bruce Moir, South Australian Film Corporation and Slater Sound Studios
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Conditioning for Sport”.
Gives an insight into the specific exercises, training and conditioning techniques necessary for proficiency in running. Describes how the body adjusts to new levels of achievement with the proper training.
